SEMI C29-0301SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINE FOR $4 . 9 \%$ HYDROFLUORIC ACID(10:1 v/v)

These specifications and this guideline were technically approved by the Global Process Chemicals Committee and are the direct responsibility of the North American Process Chemicals Committee.  Current edition approved by the North American Regional Standards Committee on October 17, 1999.  Initially available at www.semi.org February 2001; to be published March 2001.  This document replaces SEMI C7.4, C8.4, and C12.3 in their entirety.  Originally published in 1990, 1992, and 1995 respectively; previously published June 1999.

SEMI C29-0301SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINE FOR $4 . 9 \%$ HYDROFLUORIC ACID(10:1 v/v) - # 1  Purpose

1.1  The purpose of this document is to standardize requirements for $4 . 9 \%$ hydrofluoric acid used in the semiconductor industry and testing procedures to support those standards. Test methods have been shown to give statistically valid results. This document also provides guidelines for grades of $4 . 9 \%$ hydrofluoric acid for which a need has been identified. In the case of the guidelines, the test methods may not have been statistically validated yet.

SEMI C29-0301SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINE FOR $4 . 9 \%$ HYDROFLUORIC ACID(10:1 v/v) - # 2  Scope

2.1  The scope of this document is all grades of $4 . 9 \%$ hydrofluoric acid used in the semiconductor industry.  
2.2  These standards do not purpor t to address safety issues, if any, associated with their use.  It is the responsibility of the user of these standards to establish appropriate safety and health practices and determine the applicability of regulatory limitations prior to use.

SEMI C29-0301SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINE FOR $4 . 9 \%$ HYDROFLUORIC ACID(10:1 v/v) - # 3  Limitations

3.1  None.

SEMI C29-0301SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINE FOR $4 . 9 \%$ HYDROFLUORIC ACID(10:1 v/v) - # 9.2  Trace Metals Analysis

9.2.1  The following method has giv en satisfactory results in determining metal ion impurities at the values specified for each of the following metals: aluminum (Al), arsenic (As), antimony (Sb), barium (Ba), beryllium (Be), bismuth (Bi), boron (B), calcium $\mathrm { ( C a ) }$ , chromium $( \mathrm { C r } )$ , cobalt $\scriptstyle ( \mathbf { C o } )$ , copper $\mathbf { \Pi } ( \mathbf { C u } )$ , gallium $\mathrm { ( G a ) }$ , germanium (Ge), gold (Au), iron (Fe), lead $( \mathrm { P b } )$ , lithium (Li), magnesium (Mg), manganese (Mn), molybdenum (Mo), nickel (Ni), niobium (Nb), potassium (K), silver $( \operatorname { A g } )$ , sodium (Na), strontium (Sr), tantalum (Ta), tin $( \mathsf { S } \mathrm { n } )$ , titanium $\mathrm { ( T i ) }$ , vanadium (V), zinc $( Z \boldsymbol { \mathrm { n } } )$ , and zirconium $( \mathrm { Z r } )$ . Alternate methods may be used as long as appropriate studies demonstrate a recovery between $7 5 \mathrm { - } 1 2 5 \%$ of a known sample spike for half of the value of each specified element.

SEMI C29-0301SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINE FOR $4 . 9 \%$ HYDROFLUORIC ACID(10:1 v/v) - # 9.2.2  Special Reagents

9.2.2.1  Hydrofluoric Acid, Ultra Pure — Use hydrofluoric acid specified for low metal ion content.  
9.2.2.2 $4 . 9 \%$ Hydrofluoric Acid Solution — Dilute 20 $\mathbf { g }$ of ultrapure hydrofluoric acid to $2 0 0 ~ \mathrm { g }$ using water meeting the criteria for Type E1.1 in ASTM D5127.  
9.2.2.3  Water — The water used for a ll the dilution, calibration and standards should meet at a minimum the criteria for Type E1.1 in ASTM D5127 in regard to cation analysis.  
9.2.2.4  Indium Internal Standard — Make up the internal standard solution to a concentration of 20 $\mu \mathrm { g / m L }$ (ppm) from the appropriate concentrated indium standard solution.

SEMI C29-0301SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINE FOR $4 . 9 \%$ HYDROFLUORIC ACID(10:1 v/v) - # 9.2.3  Sample Preparation

9.2.3.1  In a clean environment, place $2 0 . 0 \ \mathrm { g }$ of sample into a tared FEP bottle $( 3 0 ~ \mathrm { m L } )$ ). Add $2 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { L }$ of the indium internal standard solution. Run a reagent blank.

SEMI C29-0301SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINE FOR $4 . 9 \%$ HYDROFLUORIC ACID(10:1 v/v) - # 9.2.4  Analysis

9.2.4.1  Using the prepared solutions a nd blanks, analyze sodium, potassium, calcium and iron by graphite furnace atomic absorption (GFAA) and the remaining elements by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP/MS). For calibration, the standards are made up with the $4 . 9 \%$ hydrofluoric acid solution and a final concentration of $2 0 ~ \mathrm { n g / g }$ of the indium internal standard.  
NOTE 3: Analysis of diluted hydrofluoric acid requires the use of special hydrofluoric acid resistant sample introduction systems for inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry. These systems are available from most instrument suppliers.  
NOTE 4: Analysis of diluted hydrofluoric acid can produce rapid corrosion of nickel cones commonly used in inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, platinum cones should be considered as alternative when performing this analysis.

SEMI C30-1101SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR HYDROGEN PEROXIDE

These specifications and guidelines were technically approved by the Global Process Chemicals Committee and are the direct responsibility of the North American Process Chemicals Committee.  Current edition approved by the North American Regional Standards Committee on August 27, 2001.  Initially available at www.semi.org September 2001; to be published November 2001.  This document replaces SEMI C1.9, C7.5, C8.5, C11.4, and C12.4 in their entirety.  Originally published in 1978, 1990, 1992, 1994, and 1995 respectively; previously published March 2001.

SEMI C30-1101SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR HYDROGEN PEROXIDE - # 1  Purpose

1.1  The purpose of this document is to standardize requirements for hydrogen peroxide used in the semiconductor industry and testing procedures to support those standards. Test methods have been shown to give statistically valid results. This document also provides guidelines for grades of hydrogen peroxide for which a need has been identified. In the case of the guidelines, the test methods may not have been statistically validated yet.

SEMI C30-1101SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR HYDROGEN PEROXIDE - # 2  Scope

2.1  The scope of this document is all grades of hydrogen peroxide used in the semiconductor industry.  
2.2  The VLSI grade purity level is typically required by semiconductor devices with geometries of 0.8–1.2 microns.  
2.3  This standard does not purport to address safety issues, if any, associated with its use.  It is the responsibility of the users of this standard to establish appropriate safety and health practices and determine the applicability of regulatory limitations prior to use.

SEMI C30-1101SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR HYDROGEN PEROXIDE - # 3  Limitations

3.1  The specification for VLSI grade hydrogen peroxide is only applicable for materials that remain below $2 5 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ during transport and storage.

Title: SEMI C30-1101SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR HYDROGEN PEROXIDE - # 8.9.2  Sample Preparation

Content: 8.9.2.1 Sodium and Potassium — In a clean environment, place $1 0 . 0 ~ \mathrm { \ m L }$ of water in a clean platinum crucible. Slowly add $5 . 0 \ \mathrm { \ m L }$ of hydrogen peroxide. Allow to stand at room temperature until the effervescence ceases (approximately 20 minutes). Swirl. If swirling does not produce any more bubbles, proceed with analysis. If bubbles remain, allow to stand for 5 minutes and repeat the swirl until no bubbles are produced. Run a water blank. 8.9.2.2 Other Elements — Two separate samples of hydrogen peroxide are acidified to $2 \%$ with hydrochloric acid for the analysis of tin and to $2 \%$ with nitric acid for the analysis of (specified elements). Standard additions of tin to the matrix acidified with hydrochloric acid and standard additions of other specified elements to the matrix acidified with nitric acid are added to determine the response for each element in the peroxide matrix. Aqueous acidified standards for tin in $2 \%$ hydrochloric acid and other specified elements in $2 \%$

SEMI C30-1101SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR HYDROGEN PEROXIDE - # 8.9.2  Sample Preparation (Part 2)

Title: SEMI C30-1101SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR HYDROGEN PEROXIDE - # 8.9.2  Sample Preparation

Content: nitric acid should be used to determine instrument responses.

SEMI C30-1101SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR HYDROGEN PEROXIDE - # 8.9.3  Analysis

8.9.3.1  Using the solution from Section 8.9.2.1, analyze for specified group 1 elements by flame atomic absorption spectroscopy. All other elements analyzed by plasma emission spectroscopy.

Assay Color (APHA) Free Acid  
9.2  TOC

SEMI C30-1101SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR HYDROGEN PEROXIDE - # 9.2.1  Equipment

9.2.1.1  TOC analyzer capable of analyzing total organic carbon in water.  
9.2.1.2  Platinum sheet $1 \times 1$ inch, heated in a muffle oven at $8 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ for 15 minutes.

SEMI C30-1101SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR HYDROGEN PEROXIDE - # 9.2.2  Special Reagents

9.2.2.1  Water — The water used for all of the dilution, calibration, and standards should meet, at a minimum, the criteria for Type E1.1 in ASTM D 5127 in regard to TOC analysis.  
9.2.2.2  1000 mg/mL TOC Standard (prepare fresh weekly) — Weigh accurately $0 . 2 1 2 8 \mathrm { ~ g ~ }$ of potassium acid phthalate into a $1 0 0 \ \mathrm { m L }$ volumetric flask, add water, shake to dissolve, dilute to volume, and mix well. Lower standards (prepare fresh daily) can be made by diluting an aliquot of the $\mathrm { 1 0 0 0 ~ m g / m L }$ to the appropriate volume.

SEMI C30-1101SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR HYDROGEN PEROXIDE - # 9.2.3  Sample Preparation

9.2.3.1  Weigh $5 0 \ \mathrm { ~ g ~ }$ of hydrogen peroxide, to the nearest $0 . 0 1 \ \mathrm { g }$ , into a $4 0 0 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ beaker. Add the platinum sheet to the sample, cover the beaker with a Teflon watch glass, and allow the reaction to go overnight (12 hours minimum). Transfer the solution to a $5 0 ~ \mathrm { \ m L }$ volumetric flask, dilute with water, meeting the criteria for Type E1.1 in ASTM D 5127, to a final volume of 50 mL.

SEMI C30-1101SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR HYDROGEN PEROXIDE - # 9.2.4  Analysis

9.2.4.1  Using the prepared solutions, analyze TOC by the total organic carbon analyzer after the instrument has been calibrated with 0, 4, 10, and $2 0 \mu \mathrm { g / m L }$ of TOC standards.

SEMI C30-1101SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR HYDROGEN PEROXIDE - # 9.3  Anions

9.3.1  The following method has given satisfactory results in determining anion impurities at the values specified for each of the following anions: chloride (Cl), phosphate $\left( \mathrm { P O } _ { 4 } \right)$ , nitrate $( \mathsf { N O } _ { 3 } )$ , and sulfate $\mathrm { ( S O _ { 4 } ) }$ . Alternate methods may be used as long as appropriate studies demonstrate a recovery between $7 5 \mathrm { - } 1 2 5 \%$ of a known sample spike for half of the value of each specified anion.

SEMI C30-1101SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR HYDROGEN PEROXIDE - # 9.3.2  Special Reagents

9.3.2.1  Eluent — Prepare an eluent solution that is 2.2 mM sodium carbonate $\left( \mathrm { N a } _ { 2 } \mathrm { C O } _ { 3 } \right)$ and $0 . 7 5 ~ \mathrm { m M }$ sodium bicarbonate $\mathrm { ( N a H C O _ { 3 } ) }$ ) in deionized water meeting the criteria for Type E1.1 in ASTM D 5127. Store eluent under a helium gas blanket.  
9.3.2.2  Regenerant — Prepare a $0 . 0 2 5 \mathrm { ~ N ~ }$ sulfuric acid $\mathrm { ( H } _ { 2 } \mathrm { S O } _ { 4 } )$ in deionized water meeting the criteria for Type E1.1 in ASTM D 5127.  
9.3.2.3  Potassium Carbonate Solution — Prepare a solution containing $5 0 0 ~ \mathrm { m g }$ of reagent grade potassium carbonate $\left( \mathrm { K } _ { 2 } \mathrm { C O } _ { 3 } \right)$ into $1 0 0 ~ \mathrm { { m L } }$ of water meeting the criteria for Type E1.1 in ASTM D 5127.

SEMI C30-1101SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR HYDROGEN PEROXIDE - # 9.3.3  Sample Preparation

9.3.3.1  In a clean environment, place $\boldsymbol { 4 0 } \ \mathrm { g }$ of sample into a clean beaker. Add $1 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ of a $5 ~ \mathrm { m g / m L }$ potassium carbonate solution and evaporate carefully (at $1 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } )$ to a volume of $0 . 5 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ . Dilute with water meeting the criteria for Type E1.1 in ASTM D 5127 to a final volume of $2 0 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ .  
NOTE 5: For safety purposes, a decomposition aid such as a platinum strip should be used.

SEMI C30-1101SPECIFICATIONS AND GUIDELINES FOR HYDROGEN PEROXIDE - # 9.3.4  Analysis

9.3.4.1  Using the prepared solutions and blanks, analyze chloride, nitrate, phosphate, and sulfate by ion chromatography. Run a reagent blank. Samples and reagent blanks should be prepared and analyzed in triplicate.  
9.3.4.2  Columns — Precolumn should be AG4-A (Dionex) or equivalent and Separation column should be AS4-A (Dionex) or equivalent.

SEMI C31-0301 SPECIFICATION FOR METHANOL - # 1  Purpose

1.1  The purpose of this document is to standardize requirements for methanol used in the semiconductor industry and testing procedures to support those standards. Test methods have been shown to give statistically valid results. This document also provides guidelines for grades of methanol for which a need has been identified. In the case of the guidelines, the test methods may not have been statistically validated yet.

SEMI C31-0301 SPECIFICATION FOR METHANOL - # 2  Scope

2.1  The scope of this document is all grades of methanol used in the semiconductor industry.  
2.2  These standards do not purpor t to address safety issues, if any, associated with their use.  It is the responsibility of the user of these standards to establish appropriate safety and health practices and determine the applicability of regulatory limitations prior to use.

SEMI C31-0301 SPECIFICATION FOR METHANOL - # 3  Limitations

SEMI C31-0301 SPECIFICATION FOR METHANOL - # 8.12  Trace Metal Analysis

8.12.1  Gold $( A u )$ — Analyze by grap hite atomic absorption using the manufacturer's recommended procedure. This technique has been shown to give satisfactory results using a 1:4 dilution and Zeeman background correction. Each laboratory must determine the appropriate dilution and background correction for its instrument to meet the specification limit.  
8.12.2  The following method has giv en satisfactory results in determining trace metal impurities at the value specified for each of the following trace metals: aluminum (Al), calcium $\mathrm { ( C a ) }$ , chromium $( \mathrm { C r } )$ , copper $\mathbf { \Pi } ( \mathbf { C u } )$ , iron $\mathrm { ( F e ) }$ , lead $( \mathrm { P b } )$ , magnesium $( \mathbf { M g } )$ , manganese (Mn), nickel (Ni), potassium (K), sodium (Na), tin $( \mathsf { S } \mathsf { n } )$ , titanium (Ti), and zinc $( Z \boldsymbol { \mathrm { n } } )$ . Alternate methods may be used as long as appropriate studies demonstrate recovery between $7 5 \textrm { - } 1 2 5 \%$ of a known sample spike for half of the value of each specified item.

SEMI C31-0301 SPECIFICATION FOR METHANOL - # 8.12.3  Special Reagents

8.12.3.1  Hydrochloric Acid, Ultra Pure — Use hydrochloric acid specified for ultra low metal ion content.  
8.12.3.2 $2 \%$ $( \nu / \nu )$ Hydrochloric Acid Solution Dilute $2 0 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ of ultra pure $1 2 \mathbf { M }$ hydrochloric acid to 1 L using water meeting the criteria for Type E1 in ASTM D5127.

SEMI C31-0301 SPECIFICATION FOR METHANOL - # 8.12.4  Sample Preparation

8.12.4.1  In a clean environment, place $2 5 0 \ \mathrm { ~ g ~ }$ of solvent in a PTFE dish. Slowly evaporate on a hot plate avoiding loss of sample by effervescence or spattering  
until approximately $1 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ of liquid remains. Take up liquid and all visible residue (from walls of dish) with 1 mL ultra pure, $1 2 \textbf { M }$ hydrochloric acid and continue heating until approximately $0 . 5 { \mathrm { ~ m L } }$ of liquid remains. No undissolved particulate matter should be observed. Otherwise repeat the addition of hydrochloric acid until all particulate matter is dissolved. Transfer quantitatively to a $5 0 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ volumetric flask using $2 \%$ (v/v) hydrochloric acid and adjust liquid level to mark. Prepare a reagent blank using the same reagents and in the same manner as for the sample concentration.

SEMI C31-0301 SPECIFICATION FOR METHANOL - # 8.12.5  Analysis

8.12.5.1  Using the prepared sample and reagent blank, analyze group I elements potassium (K) and sodium (Na) by atomic absorption spectroscopy and all other elements by plasma emission spectroscopy. Apply, if necessary, a reagent blank correction to the final determined value of the sample.  
NOTE 3: Due to the uncertainty of acid concentration in the liquid residue the final concentration can be estimated to be approximately $2 \%$ (v/v). Standard calibration solutions are to use this same acid concentration.

Current edition approved by the North American Regional Standards Committee on October 17, 1999.  Initially available at www.semi.org February 2001; to be published March 2001.  This document replaces SEMI C1.25, C7.16, and C8.11 in their entirety.  Originally published in 1986, 1992, and 1998 respectively; previously published June 1999.

SEMI C33-0301 SPECIFICATIONS FOR n-METHYL 2-PYRROLIDONE - # 1  Purpose

1.1  The purpose of this document is to standardize requirements for n-methyl 2-pyrrolidone used in the semiconductor industry and testing procedures to support those standards. Test methods have been shown to give statistically valid results. This document also provides guidelines for grades of n-methyl 2- pyrrolidone for which a need has been identified. In the case of the guidelines, the test methods may not have been statistically validated yet.

SEMI C33-0301 SPECIFICATIONS FOR n-METHYL 2-PYRROLIDONE - # 2  Scope

2.1  The scope of this document is all grades of nmethyl 2-pyrrolidone used in the semiconductor industry.  
2.2  These standards do not purpor t to address safety issues, if any, associated with their use.  It is the responsibility of the user of these standards to establish appropriate safety and health practices and determine the applicability of regulatory limitations prior to use.

SEMI C33-0301 SPECIFICATIONS FOR n-METHYL 2-PYRROLIDONE - # 8.8.1  Special Reagents

8.8.1.1  Hydrochloric Acid, Ultra Pure — Use hydrochloric acid specified for ultra low metal ion content.  
8.8.1.2  Mannitol Powder — Use mann itol specified for reagent grade (A.C.S.) and determined, via the reagent blank, to be ultra metal ion content.  
8.8.1.3 $5 \%$ Mannitol Solution — Disso lve and dilute 5 $\mathrm { \bf { g } }$ of mannitol to $1 0 0 ~ \mathrm { \ m L }$ using water meeting the criteria for Type E1.1 in ASTM D5127.  
8.8.1.4 $2 \%$ $( \nu / \nu )$ ) Hydrochloric Acid So lution — Dilute $2 0 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ of ultra pure, $1 2 \textbf { M }$ hydrochloric acid to $^ \mathrm { ~ 1 ~ L ~ }$ using water meeting the criteria for Type E1.1 in ASTM D5127.

SEMI C33-0301 SPECIFICATIONS FOR n-METHYL 2-PYRROLIDONE - # 8.8.2  Sample Preparation

8.8.2.1  In a clean environment, place $2 5 0 ~ \mathrm { g }$ of solvent in a PTFE dish. Add $0 . 5 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ of freshly prepared $5 \%$ mannitol solution. Slowly evaporate on a hot plate, avoiding loss of sample by effervescence or spattering until approximately $1 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ of liquid remains. Take up liquid and all visible residue (from walls of dish) with 1 mL ultra pure, $1 2 \textbf { M }$ hydrochloric acid and continue heating until approximately $0 . 5 { \mathrm { ~ m L } }$ of liquid remains. No undissolved particulate matter should be observed. Otherwise, repeat the addition of hydrochloric acid until all particulate matter is dissolved. Transfer quantitatively to a $5 0 ~ \mathrm { m L }$ volumetric flask using $2 \%$ (v/v) hydrochloric acid and adjust liquid level to mark. Prepare a reagent blank using the same reagents and in the same manner as for the sample concentration.

SEMI C33-0301 SPECIFICATIONS FOR n-METHYL 2-PYRROLIDONE - # 8.8.3  Analysis

8.8.3.1  Using the prepared sample and reagent blank, analyze group 1 elements potassium (K) and sodium (Na) by atomic absorption spectroscopy and all other elements by plasma emission spectrometry. Apply, if necessary, a reagent blank correction to the final determined value of the sample.

Alternative methods may be used as long as appropriate studies demonstrate a recovery between $7 5 - 1 2 5 \%$ of a known sample spike for half of the value of each specified element.

9.2.2.2  Regenerant — Prepare a $0 . 1 ~ \mathrm { ~ M ~ }$ t etrabutylammonium hydroxide (TBAOH) solution in deionized water meeting the criteria for Type E1.1 in ASTM D5127.  
9.2.3  Sample Preparation — Sample is injected neat.

SEMI C33-0301 SPECIFICATIONS FOR n-METHYL 2-PYRROLIDONE - # 9.2.4  Analysis

9.2.4.1  Using the prepared solutions a nd blanks, analyze mono-methylamine, di-methylamine, and trimethylamine by ion chromatography.  Run a reagent blank.  Samples and reagent blanks should be prepared and analyzed in triplicate.  
9.2.4.2  Columns — Precolumn should be CG2 (Dionex) or equivalent and separation column should be a CS2 (Dionex) or equivalent.
